repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Health and
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though the institutional development
            impact is only modest. Most of the lessons highlighted by
            the implementation of the project, are about project design,
            seemingly the weakest aspect of the project. The erroneous
            assumption that economic difficulties in the country were
            temporary, limited the project; instead, the development of
            a long-term multi-sector support approach, in coordination
            with other donors, could have further improved success. And,
            while the project scope should be comprehensive enough to
            achieve expected impacts, the seeming success of the health
            component, integrated to the malaria control program,
            hampered the impact of the education component, which only
            included select aspects, not addressing the severe
            limitations of the quality of primary education. However,
            while a multi-sector approach to project lending, is
            efficient in a small country, ambitious project objectives
            may hinder success; rather, attention should have been
            focused on few priorities per sector. Moreover, to attain
            significant, and sustainable impacts from the malaria
            control program, it should have been complemented by
            strengthening the broader health system to mainstream
            interventions, for the incidence of malaria is still high.
            Finally, construction works, namely the drainage works,
            prove the need for a strategic framework plan, to include a
            wetland master plan, an environmental assessment, and the
            involvement of the community.

repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Health and
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project assists the Government of
            Sao Tome and Principe in reversing the recent declines in
            the health and educational status of the population. In the
            health sector, the project supports a comprehensive program
            to control malaria, the provision of essential drugs, and
            the strengthening of health planning. In the education
            sector, the project comprises the purchase of school
            textbooks and educational materials, the strengthening of
            school inspection at the primary school level, and the
            improvement in education planning. In both sectors, the main
            institutional reform goals are to improve efficiency in
            service delivery and utilization of existing resources as
            well as mobilization of additional resources. These goals
            are to be achieved through the improvements in planning,
            management information, external assistance coordination as
            well as through the cost recovery program from the
            distribution of essential drugs and school textbooks. The
            project includes a limited number of studies in very high
            priority areas, such as nutrition, family planning and
            community involvement. The studies are aimed at improving
            the understanding of the issues and constraints, and
            recommending suitable interventions.
